title: 107_hr2238
content: The Act is titled the "Fern Lake Conservation and Recreation Act of 2001" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2 as findings and purposes. The Congress finds that Fern Lake and its watershed in Bell County, Kentucky, and Claiborne County, Tennessee, are potential additions to Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. Acquiring Fern Lake and its watershed would protect the vista from Pinnacle Overlook, enhance recreational opportunities, and safeguard the water supply for Middlesboro, Kentucky. The 4500-acre Fern Lake watershed is currently privately owned. The 4500-acre Fern Lake watershed is privately owned, with the lake and part of the watershed up for sale. The Secretary of the Interior is unable to use funds to acquire the lands. The Act aims to allow the Secretary to use funds to acquire Fern Lake and its surrounding watershed to protect natural resources and enhance recreational opportunities at Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. It also ensures the continued water supply from Fern Lake to Middlesboro, Kentucky. The Act allows the Secretary of the Interior to use funds to acquire Fern Lake and its surrounding watershed to protect natural resources and enhance recreational opportunities at Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. The Secretary of the Interior is authorized to acquire approximately 4,500 acres of land, including Fern Lake and its surrounding watershed, to add to Cumberland Gap National Historical Park. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land for Cumberland Gap National Historical Park, including Fern Lake and its watershed, through donation, purchase, or exchange with owner consent. Easements may be acquired for water supply facilities from Fern Lake to Middlesboro, Kentucky. The Secretary is authorized to acquire land for Cumberland Gap National Historical Park, including Fern Lake and its watershed, through donation, purchase, or exchange with owner consent. Upon acquisition, the Secretary will adjust the park boundaries to include the land and administer it according to park regulations. Special issues related to Fern Lake include managing recreational use to protect the water supply for Middlesboro, Kentucky, and environs. The Secretary will sell untreated water from Fern Lake to a utility serving Middlesboro, Kentucky, ensuring equitable terms to balance park protection and water supply needs. Proceeds from the water sale will provide a reasonable return to the United States. The Secretary will consult with officials and organizations in Kentucky, Tennessee, and Virginia to manage Fern Lake and its watershed for water supply and recreational opportunities. The House of Representatives passed the document on December 5, 2001, as attested by Clerk Jeff Trandahl.
